attributes.text:
Mixin for the linear background gradient CSS property. This mixin is usually used by {@link qx.ui.decoration.Decorator}.

Keep in mind that this is not supported by all browsers:

  • Safari 4.0+
  • Chrome 4.0+
  • Firefox 3.6+
  • Opera 11.1+
  • IE 10+
  • IE 5.5+ (with limitations)

For IE 5.5 to IE 8,this class uses the filter rules to create the gradient. This has some limitations: The start and end position property can not be used. For more details, see the original documentation: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms532997(v=vs.85).aspx

For IE9, we create a gradient in a canvas element and render this gradient as background image. Due to restrictions in the background-image css property, we can not allow negative start values in that case.

It is possible to define multiple background gradients by setting an array containing the needed values as the property value. In case multiple values are specified, the values of the properties are repeated until all match in length. It is not possible to define multiple background gradients when falling back to filter rules (IE5.5 to IE8).

An example:

  'my-decorator': {
    style: {
      startColor:['rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)', 'rgba(0, 255, 0, 0.5)', 'rgba(0, 0, 255, 0.5)'],
      endColor: 'rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.2)',
      orientation: ['horizontal', 'vertical']
    }
  }

which is the same as:

  'my-decorator': {
    style: {
      startColor: ['rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)', 'rgba(0, 255, 0, 0.5)', 'rgba(0, 0, 255, 0.5)'],
      endColor: ['rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.2)', 'rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.2)', 'rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.2)'],
      orientation: ['horizontal', 'vertical', 'horizontal']
    }
  }
The color name
Helper to get a resolved color from a name
The resolved color
The color to start the gradient with
The color to end the gradient with
The unit in which startColorPosition and endColorPosition are measured
Either ‘horizontal’ or ‘vertical’
The position of the gradient’s starting point, measured in `unit` units along the `orientation` axis from top or left
The position of the gradient’s ending point, measured in `unit` units along the `orientation` axis from top or left
The complete styles currently poised to be applied by decorators. Should not be written to in this method (use `backgroundStyle` for that)
This method should push new background styles onto this array.

Compute CSS rules to style the background with gradients. This can be called multiple times and SHOULD layer the gradients on top of each other and on top of existing backgrounds. Default implementation (uses spec-compliant syntax).
Whether this implementation supports multiple gradients atop each other (true).
The color to start the gradient with
The color to end the gradient with
The unit in which startColorPosition and endColorPosition are measured
Either ‘horizontal’ or ‘vertical’
The position of the gradient’s starting point, measured in `unit` units along the `orientation` axis from top or left
The position of the gradient’s ending point, measured in `unit` units along the `orientation` axis from top or left
The complete styles currently poised to be applied by decorators. Should not be written to in this method (use `backgroundStyle` for that)
This method should push new background styles onto this array.

Compute CSS rules to style the background with gradients. This can be called multiple times and SHOULD layer the gradients on top of each other and on top of existing backgrounds. Legacy implementation for old WebKit browsers (Chrome < 10).
Whether this implementation supports multiple gradients atop each other (true).
The color to start the gradient with
The color to end the gradient with
The unit in which startColorPosition and endColorPosition are measured
Either ‘horizontal’ or ‘vertical’
The position of the gradient’s starting point, measured in `unit` units along the `orientation` axis from top or left
The position of the gradient’s ending point, measured in `unit` units along the `orientation` axis from top or left
The complete styles currently poised to be applied by decorators. Should not be written to in this method (use `backgroundStyle` for that)
This method should push new background styles onto this array.

Compute CSS rules to style the background with gradients. This can be called multiple times and SHOULD layer the gradients on top of each other and on top of existing backgrounds. IE9 canvas solution.
Whether this implementation supports multiple gradients atop each other (true).
The color to start the gradient with
The color to end the gradient with
The unit in which startColorPosition and endColorPosition are measured
Either ‘horizontal’ or ‘vertical’
The position of the gradient’s starting point, measured in `unit` units along the `orientation` axis from top or left
The position of the gradient’s ending point, measured in `unit` units along the `orientation` axis from top or left

The complete styles currently poised to be applied by decorators. Should not be written to in this method (use `backgroundStyle` for that). Note: this particular implementation will do that because it needs to change the `filter` property.
This method should push new background styles onto this array.

Compute CSS rules to style the background with gradients. This can be called multiple times and SHOULD layer the gradients on top of each other and on top of existing backgrounds. Old IE filter fallback.
Whether this implementation supports multiple gradients atop each other (false).
new value of the property
previous value of the property (null if it was not yet set).

Applies changes of the property value of the properties colorPositionUnit, endColor, endColorPosition, orientation, startColor and startColorPosition.

For further details take a look at the property definitions: {@link #colorPositionUnit}, {@link #endColor}, {@link #endColorPosition}, {@link #orientation}, {@link #startColor} and {@link #startColorPosition}.
A map to add the styles.
Takes a styles map and adds the linear background styles in place to the given map. This is the needed behavior for {@link qx.ui.decoration.Decorator}.

Returns the (computed) value of the property colorPositionUnit.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #colorPositionUnit}.
(Computed) value of colorPositionUnit.

Returns the (computed) value of the property endColor.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #endColor}.
(Computed) value of endColor.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #endColorPosition}.

Initial value for property colorPositionUnit.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property colorPositionUnit with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #colorPositionUnit}.
the default value

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #startColorPosition}.
the default value

Resets the user value of the property colorPositionUnit.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #colorPositionUnit}.

Resets the user value of the property endColor.

Defines if the given positions are in % or px.
End color of the background gradient. Note that alpha transparency (rgba) is not supported in IE 8.
Position in percent where to start the color.
Property group to set the end color including its end position.
Property group to set the start color including its start position.
The orientation of the gradient.
Start color of the background gradient. Note that alpha transparency (rgba) is not supported in IE 8.
